caption: TABLE I: Mapping table of the input prompts and the activated elements.
description: This table shows how different input types (video, image, text, tag, humming) are processed by the XProjector component of the XMusic framework.  It indicates which symbolic music elements (emotion, rhythm, notes, genre) are activated for each input type, guiding the subsequent music generation process. For example, video and humming prompts primarily activate rhythm and notes, as they contain temporal information, while images, text and tags mainly activate emotion, or both emotion and genre.

caption: TABLE II: Comparison of the implementation details between the CP and our proposed representation.
description: This table details the implementation differences between the Compound Word (CP) representation from a prior work and the enhanced representation proposed in this paper.  It compares the vocabulary size and embedding size for various token types in both representations, highlighting the additions and modifications made to the CP model.  The token types include those related to instrument, tempo, position/bar, chord, pitch, duration, velocity, family type, density, strength, emotion, and genre, illustrating the expanded capabilities of the new representation.

caption: TABLE III: Comparison between existing emotion-labeled MIDI datasets and the proposed XMIDI dataset.
description: This table compares the XMIDI dataset with other existing emotion-labeled MIDI datasets.  It provides a quantitative comparison across several key aspects: the number of emotion classes used for annotation, the types of genres included, and the total number of songs (or MIDI files) in each dataset. This allows for a clear understanding of XMIDI's scale and comprehensiveness relative to existing resources in the field of symbolic music generation.

caption: TABLE IV: Objective comparison with state-of-the-art symbolic music generation methods.
description: This table presents an objective comparison of XMusic with state-of-the-art symbolic music generation methods across three key metrics: Pitch Class Histogram Entropy (PCE), Grooving Pattern Similarity (GS), and Empty Beat Rate (EBR). Lower PCE values indicate clearer tonality, higher GS scores suggest stronger rhythm, and lower EBR scores imply richer note distribution.  The comparison is split into two parts: unconditioned and video-conditioned generation, reflecting different input types used for music generation.

caption: TABLE V: Subjective comparison with state-of-the-art symbolic music generation methods.
description: This table presents a subjective comparison of XMusic with state-of-the-art symbolic music generation methods across various prompt types (unconditioned, video-conditioned, text-conditioned, and image-conditioned).  Human participants evaluated the generated music based on several criteria (Richness, Correctness, Structuredness, Emotion-Matching, and Rhythm-Matching) to rank the quality of the output from each model. The ranking scores reveal XMusic's relative strengths in each category.

caption: TABLE VI: Subjective comparison with state-of-the-art emotion-conditioned symbolic music generation method.
description: This table presents a subjective comparison of XMusic against the state-of-the-art emotion-conditioned symbolic music generation method, EMOPIA.  It uses a human evaluation to assess the accuracy of emotion classification for four broad emotion categories (positive valence positive arousal, negative valence positive arousal, negative valence negative arousal, positive valence negative arousal) generated by both systems. The results are presented as percentages showing the proportion of music pieces correctly classified by human evaluators for each emotion category. This allows for a direct comparison of the accuracy of emotion representation between the two systems.

caption: TABLE VII: Ablation analysis.
description: This ablation study analyzes the impact of different components and design choices within the XMusic framework on the overall music generation quality. It presents a comparative analysis of various settings, including the presence of the Selector, the type of emotion control (none, music-level, or bar-level), the music representation used (CP, CP with added features), and the data sampling technique (undersampling, oversampling, original dataset). The results for each setting are evaluated based on multiple aspects, namely richness, correctness, structuredness, emotion-matching, rhythm-matching and the overall rank. This allows for a comprehensive understanding of the contribution of each component to the final music generation quality.

caption: TABLE VIII: Comparison with state-of-the-art symbolic music generation methods on public datasets.
description: Table VIII presents a comparison of the XMusic model's performance against state-of-the-art symbolic music generation methods on publicly available datasets.  Specifically, it shows a quantitative comparison of the subjective quality aspects (richness, correctness, and structuredness) of music generated by XMusic and other methods on the AILabs1k7 and EMOPIA datasets.  This allows for a direct assessment of XMusic's performance in terms of generating high-quality symbolic music relative to existing approaches.

caption: TABLE IX: Objective ablation study on the proposed Selector.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study on the impact of the proposed Selector module in the XMusic framework.  The study examines the objective metrics (PCE, GS, and EBR) achieved when the Selector is included versus when it is excluded. This allows assessment of the Selector's effectiveness in improving the overall quality of the generated music.

caption: TABLE X: Ablation study on the multi-task learning scheme of the Selector.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study investigating the impact of the multi-task learning scheme on the Selector's performance.  The Selector is a component of the XMusic framework, responsible for identifying high-quality generated music. The study evaluates the model's accuracy in classifying the quality, emotion, and genre of the music by systematically removing tasks from the multi-task learning setup. This allows for a detailed examination of how each task contributes to the overall performance of the Selector and provides insights into the effectiveness of the multi-task learning approach.

caption: TABLE XI: Ablation analysis on the weighting factors λ1subscript𝜆1\lambda_{1}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and λ2subscript𝜆2\lambda_{2}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of image emotion recognition task.
description: This table presents the results of an ablation study investigating the impact of different weighting factors (λ1 and λ2) applied to the image emotion recognition task within the XMusic model.  The study varied the weights assigned to two different methods for emotion recognition from images (ResNet and CLIP), testing various combinations to determine the optimal balance for achieving the highest accuracy.  The table shows the accuracy achieved for each tested combination of weighting factors.
